title: Trump, Biden Campaign Travels Show Expanded Battleground Map
summary: The president is in Florida while Biden and Pence hit Ohio, both states where Trump is playing defense after winning in 2016.

title: Cuomo Unveils Statue of Mother Cabrini in New York City
summary: Bronze statue honors Italian immigrant who became first naturalized American citizen to be canonized. New York Gov. Andrew Cuomo helped unveil a new statue Monday to honor Mother Cabrini, a popular Roman Catholic saint who was at the center of a controversy last year over a New York City initiative to build statues honoring famous women.

title: California Election Official Demands State GOP Remove Ballot Drop Boxes
summary: Republicans' ballot boxes are too similar to official ones, secretary of state says. California's top election official on Monday sent letters to state Republican officials demanding that they immediately remove ballot drop-off boxes that he said improperly resembled official ones set up by local governments.

title: Trump Tests Negative for Covid-19 on Consecutive Days
summary: Doctor says president is 'not infectious to others' as he traveled to Florida for rally. WASHINGTON-President Trump tested negative for Covid-19 on consecutive days, White House physician Sean Conley said in a memo released Monday as Mr. Trump traveled to Florida for his first campaign rally since being treated for the virus.

title: What Happens When Employers Shorten the Workweek?
summary: The theory is that shortening working hours could reduce stress, lower absenteeism and boost employment. Some have advocated for four-day workweeks as a way to keep people employed during the Covid-19 pandemic. But the evidence about whether or not shorter working hours are beneficial for workers and economies is mixed.

title: New York Can Stop a Second Wave of Covid-19, Gov. Cuomo Says
summary: Governor's remarks follow decision last week to close schools and ban large gatherings in certain ultra-Orthodox Jewish areas. New York Gov. Andrew Cuomo on Monday touted the benefits of targeted shutdowns in preventing a second wave of Covid-19 after tightening restrictions last week in response to a rise in cases in parts of New York City.

title: PC Demand During Pandemic Fuels Strongest U.S. Market Growth in a Decade
summary: Chromebook shipments surged about 90% in the third quarter because of distance learning. A surge in remote work, study and home entertainment during the coronavirus pandemic boosted personal computer sales in the third quarter and drove the strongest growth in a decade in the U.S., according to industry data.

title: Disney Elevates Streaming Unit in Reorganization
summary: Company forms new content and distribution arms as pandemic hammers entertainment industry. Walt Disney Co. announced a major reorganization meant to give priority to its streaming-video services and ensure they get a steady flow of the company's best content, in a shift echoing similar moves by other entertainment giants.

title: Do Babies Need to Eat Meat?
summary: For its first-ever dietary guidelines for children under 2, the USDA weighs recommendations for a diet including fruit, vegetables-and meat, prompting objections from plant-based advocates. A federal committee's recommendations for what babies and toddlers should eat highlight growing concerns about nutrient deficiencies and later obesity. But advice that youngsters eat a significant amount of meat is spurring a backlash from advocates of plant-based diets.

title: Republicans, Democrats Clash at Confirmation Hearing for Amy Coney Barrett
summary: Democrats focus on Affordable Care Act, while Republicans accuse them of trying to turn court into arm of the legislature. WASHINGTON-Senators clashed over confirming Amy Coney Barrett to the Supreme Court at hearings that began on Monday with opening statements, with Republicans brushing aside Democratic objections about the push to act just ahead of Election Day and cement a conservative majority on the court that could last for a generation.

title: Wisconsin Says Foxconn Doesn't Qualify for Subsidies
summary: Company had projected investing over $3 billion by 2019; it has invested $300 million, according to the state. Wisconsin officials have denied a request by Foxconn Technology Group for the first payments in what had been envisioned as $3 billion in state subsidies for a major technology complex President Trump hailed as the "eighth wonder of the world."

title: Amy Coney Barrett Should Refuse to Recuse
summary: She'd have a duty to hear election cases if she's confirmed.. The Senate began confirmation hearings Monday for Judge Amy Coney Barrett, and Democrats know they're unlikely to block her ascension to the Supreme Court. So they're rolling out a supposed ethics test that if she joins the Court she must recuse herself on cases related to the presidential election.

title: Congrats, Illinois, You'll Be 47th!
summary: A new progressive tax would send the state into New Jersey and New York territory.. Illinois voters will decide next month whether to enact a progressive income tax, paving the way for a new top rate of 7.99%. In addition to the direct damage higher rates would inflict on bottom lines, voters should consider the high-tax neighborhood they'd be moving to.

title: Dr. Fauci Protests Too Much
summary: He objects to a campaign ad, though Trump took his advice on Covid-19.. In the case of Anthony Fauci vs. Donald Trump, the National Institutes of Health (NIH) doctor and the media say the Trump campaign is running an ad that takes Dr. Fauci's words in vain. Readers can decide, so let's go to the videotape.

title: Covid-19 Reinfection Documented in Nevada Adds to Questions on Virus Immunity
summary: Case of man reinfected with the coronavirus, reported in a Lancet medical journal, joins a number of Covid-19 second-cases world-wide. A Nevada man became the first published case of Covid-19 reinfection in the U.S., adding to a number of examples world-wide signaling that patients who have recovered from the viral disease might still be at risk of getting it again.

title: New U.S. Coronavirus Infections Fall but Remain Elevated in Midwest
summary: In Wisconsin, seven-day average of new cases hit 2,510 as of Sunday. The U.S. reported fewer than 50,000 new coronavirus cases for the first time in five days, while cases remained elevated in several states, particularly in the Midwest.

title: McDonald's, Chipotle and Domino's Are Booming While Neighborhood Restaurants Struggle
summary: A health crisis is creating a divide in the restaurant world. Big, well-capitalized chains are thriving while small independents struggle to keep their kitchens open.. The coronavirus pandemic is splitting the restaurant industry in two. Big, well capitalized chains like Chipotle Mexican Grill Inc. and Domino's Pizza Inc. are gaining customers and adding stores while tens of thousands of local eateries go bust.

title: Election 2020 and 'the Invisible'
summary: Backers of Trump and Biden have different views on the potency of unseen forces.. American politics will inevitably take a metaphysical turn this week. Behind the headlines about a Supreme Court nominee, debate rescheduling and national polling in the closing days of a contentious presidential election lie divergent attitudes about a powerful force that can't be seen. Call it "the invisible."

title: Thank These Nobel Laureates for Your Cellphone
summary: Economists Paul Milgrom and Richard Wilson get the prize for devising spectrum auctions.. On Monday the Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences awarded the Nobel Prize in Economic Sciences to two American economists at Stanford, 83-year-old Robert B. Wilson and 72-year-old Paul R. Milgrom. The citation was "for improvements to auction theory and inventions of new auction formats."

title: Southwest Airlines to Challenge Rivals at O'Hare and in Houston
summary: New service will take on United and American, as the carriers fight Covid-19's impact. Southwest Airlines Co. is pushing into two of the largest U.S. airports, signaling its plan to grab market share from bigger rivals hobbled by the coronavirus pandemic.

title: 'The Luckiest Man' Review: Remembering a Maverick
summary: Sen. John McCain-war hero, wisecracker, hothead, unconventional politician-never achieved the ofﬁce he wanted and deserved.. The late John McCain's paternal line was touched by a kind of tragic greatness. The senator's grandfather, "Slew" McCain, a brilliant and courageous admiral in the Pacific during World War II, dropped dead four days after the Japanese surrender; he was only 61 but, after years of high stress and hard drinking, looked far older. His son, John S. McCain Jr., a celebrated submarine commander during the war, rose to command the entire Pacific fleet during the Vietnam War. But an inner anguish, no doubt exacerbated by his own son's imprisonment in North Vietnam for five years, drove Jack McCain, as he was known, to a debilitating alcoholism.

title: Amy Coney Barrett and the Ivies
summary: Harvard and Yale worry what the newest justice would mean for their racial-preference policies.. Amy Coney Barrett has Harvard and Yale worried. Not because her law degree breaks their lock on Supreme Court justices. But because these Ivy League schools' use of race in their college admissions is now before the federal courts-and they fear Judge Barrett will be the decisive vote against them if she's confirmed to the Supreme Court.

title: Why Trump Doesn't Need to Wear a Mask
summary: You should wear one now, whether you've had the virus or not. But he no longer needs to.. President Trump should have worn a mask before he got the coronavirus. You should wear a mask now, whether you've had it or not. But he no longer needs to.

title: A World of Geopolitical Opportunity
summary: America's global position is stronger today than in 2016 in some important ways.. As pandemic and polarization sweep the country, the U.S. has fallen into one of its periodic episodes of self-flagellation and existential doubt. That is not a bad thing. Constant self-examination and a refusal to settle for the status quo are part of the dynamic culture that makes America work. Whether we have a Biden administration or a Trump second term, however, U.S. policy makers need to look past the angst and despair.

title: A Big Montecito Estate Sells for Little Over Half Its Original $125 Million Asking Price
summary: The 237-acre property known as Rancho San Carlos fetched $63.25 million. One of the largest residential properties in Montecito, Calif., a popular haven for the wealthy, has sold for $63.25 million, about half of its original $125 million asking price, property records show.

title: Grand Central Oyster Bar Closes After Reopening at Limited Capacity
summary: Famed restaurant in Grand Central Terminal says business was too slow, with sales reaching only 3% of pre-pandemic levels. Less than two weeks after it reopened for indoor dining, the Grand Central Oyster Bar, one of New York City's most famed restaurants, has closed its doors again-at least for the time being.

title: Billy Beane Set to Leave Baseball Behind in Fenway Sports Deal
summary: He could turn to other sports ventures, including European soccer, working with billionaire John Henry. The proposed deal to take the parent company of the Boston Red Sox public leaves Billy Beane, the Oakland Athletics executive of "Moneyball" fame who ignited the data revolution in American sports, with a difficult choice.

title: Here's What Leaving Silicon Valley Could Mean for Tech Workers' Pay
summary: Some tech workers who leave the San Francisco Bay Area face pay cuts depending on where they move. Workers for big tech companies in the Bay Area who are relocating to work remotely might be forced to take a pay cut, depending on where they choose to live. The new pay-cut movement stands to create tension between some of the most profitable companies in the world and their skilled and highly paid employees.

title: Many Corporate Boards Still Face Shortage of Tech Expertise
summary: But more CIOs are expected to earn a seat as the pandemic forces companies to lean on digital. Corporate boards could soon be on the hunt for fresh technology expertise as digital business models pursued in the wake of the coronavirus pandemic reshape business strategy.

title: Covid-19 Cases Climb in New Jersey, Worrying Health Officials
summary: State's seven-day rolling average has bounced back up to levels last seen in June. Hospitalizations and new cases of Covid-19 are creeping up in New Jersey as the state prepares for a potential second wave in the fall and winter months.

title: Construction Magnate Gives $300 Million to Alma Mater
summary: Gift to Missouri University of Science and Technology is among largest ever to a college. A 91-year-old New York native who moved to Missouri to finish college and made a fortune building hospitals gave $300 million to his alma mater, the Missouri University of Science and Technology, the school announced Monday. It is one of the largest private gifts to a university on record.

title: Nobel Prize in Economics Is Awarded for Invention of New Auction Formats
summary: The prize is shared by two Stanford professors for their invention of new auction formats. U.S. academics Paul R. Milgrom and Robert B. Wilson have been awarded the Nobel Prize in Economic Sciences for new insights into how auctions work, and how different auction designs can help buyers and sellers meet their goals.

title: What You Need to Know About Covid-19 and Pregnancy
summary: Some recent studies found that pregnant women with Covid-19 mostly deliver healthy babies. But other research shows virus-related risks including illness and premature birth. Doctors know that viruses can cause complications in pregnancy and now they are racing to understand the effect of Covid-19. So far there is evidence of risks, but they may not be as severe as the complications from influenza and some other viruses.

title: 'Anime, Trauma and Divorce' by Open Mike Eagle Review: Life Gone Wrong
summary: In the wake of his marriage's dissolution and a string of professional setbacks, the rapper issues a downbeat, honest and darkly comic album..

title: Tech Stocks Power Markets Higher
summary: Megacap companies including Apple and Amazon.com were among the strongest performers. U.S. stocks jumped sharply Monday, propelled by technology stocks that led major indexes to their highest closing values in nearly six weeks.

title: Is the Cure for Racism Really More Racism?
summary: The "discrimination" critical race theorists want to "remedy" through still more discrimination, is any failure to meet a racial quota.. Christopher Rufo misses the main problem with critical race theory ("The Truth About Critical Race Theory," op-ed, Oct. 5). Yes, it is dehumanizing political indoctrination. But its real vice is that it teaches people to commit constitutional violations.

title: Trump's Past Tax Records Are Irrelevant Now
summary: Releasing them serves no useful purpose other than as talking points for his enemies.. Regarding your editorial "Trump's Unhappy Returns" (Sept. 29): After almost four years as president, Donald Trump's tax records are irrelevant, and releasing them serves no useful purpose other than as talking points for his enemies. We don't want to know about President Trump's taxes. We do want to know why various companies and countries around the world gave Hunter Biden, the son of a sitting vice president, millions of dollars for doing essentially nothing. Unlike four years ago, President Trump now has a record. Like him or not, we now know how he operates and how he'll perform going forward, which is more than can be said of either Joe Biden or Kamala Harris. Illegally releasing confidential IRS records is another dirty trick by the anti-Trumpers and will only discourage successful business people from running for elective office in the future.

title: Purdue Responds on Judge Amy Coney Barrett's Title IX Opinion
summary: The general counsel says the school was a strong advocate of the need for Title IX rule-making and has long sought to ensure evenhandedness and neutrality in student misconduct discipline.. History professor KC Johnson ("Sex, Due Process and Amy Coney Barrett," op-ed, Oct. 1) misreads Judge Amy Coney Barrett's opinion about a male student's allegation that he was wrongly disciplined by Purdue in a Title IX case. When an appeals court considers a motion to dismiss-such as the one made by Purdue in this case-the court looks only at the complaint and must assume the plaintiff's alleged facts to be true. At the time of Judge Barrett's opinion, none of Purdue's evidence was before the court.

title: CEOs Increasingly See Sustainability as Path to Profitability
summary: Ilham Kadri, who heads Belgian chemical company Solvay, is among a growing group of leaders who say sustainability will play a role in their company's future success. If Solvay SA wasn't serious about sustainability, Ilham Kadri says, she wouldn't have taken the chief executive job last year.

title: Wisconsin Judge Upholds Governor's Mask Order
summary: Ruling comes as state ranks third behind Texas and California for total new Covid-19 cases. A Wisconsin judge has upheld an order from Gov. Tony Evers declaring a public health emergency and requiring masks to be worn in enclosed spaces across the state, where a rise in Covid-19 cases is overwhelming some local hospitals.

title: Facebook Bans Content Denying the Holocaust on Its Platforms
summary: How Facebook dealt with content disputing the Holocaust has been a longstanding subject of controversy. Facebook Inc. said it would begin removing Holocaust denials or distortions from its social-media platforms, a move that follows years of complaints from civil-rights groups that the company tolerated hate speech and enabled the spread of misinformation.

title: Now They're After Lincoln
summary: Columbus shouldn't take the cancel campaign personally.. It's hard to keep up with the list of contributors to American liberty deemed unacceptable by violent protesters who appear to be contributing nothing. But for anyone still trying to make the effort, President Abraham Lincoln is the latest villain in the narrative of the radical left.

title: Public-Health Experts Rethink Lockdowns as Covid Cases Surge
summary: Policy makers are reluctant to reimpose the nationwide lockdowns they used in the spring, worried people won't tolerate draconian new curbs. As Covid-19 cases surge across large parts of Europe and the U.S., officials are reluctant to force another round of nationwide lockdowns of the sort imposed in March.

title: Bed Bath & Beyond CFO Looks to Declutter Shelves, Reduce Working Capital
summary: Home-goods retailer plans to close 200 stores over the course of two years and unveil a new store model later this month. Bed Bath & Beyond Inc. is looking at fewer stores stocked with less stuff as a way to limit the amount of cash trapped in its operations.

title: A Whimsical Home on Southampton's Meadow Lane
summary: With a wood-shingled roof that resembles thatching, the house wouldn't look out of place in the English Cotswolds. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: Natural Gas Surges as Traders Brace for Cold Winter
summary: Prices rose toward their highest level in nearly two years, extending recent rally. Natural-gas prices rose to their highest level in more than a year and a half on Monday, extending a recent rally with traders preparing for colder temperatures and assessing the impact of weather-related supply disruptions.

title: Twilio to Acquire Customer-Data Firm for $3.2 Billion
summary: All-stock deal is reached for software provider Segment. Twilio Inc. agreed to acquire a software provider that focuses on helping businesses track and manage customer data, a $3.2 billion deal that comes as companies rethink how they reach consumers who are spending more time at home during the Covid-19 pandemic.

title: Coronavirus Stimulus Spending Consensus Eludes Global Leaders
summary: Finance ministers and central bankers meet this week at annual meetings of World Bank and IMF. WASHINGTON-Early in the coronavirus pandemic, global policy makers were united around the need for massive fiscal stimulus to inoculate their economies and bring them back to health.

title: Surging Online Sales Drive Growth for Shopify's Fulfillment Service
summary: E-commerce technology provider's second-quarter revenue nearly doubled as merchants scaled up digital sales. Shopify Inc.'s recent expansion into physical distribution is looking prescient, as surging digital sales during the coronavirus pandemic boost demand for the e-commerce technology company's fulfillment services.

title: Zoom Will Need to Start Phoning It In
summary: The videoconferencing superstar has become a household name but will soon need to show it can tap new markets. In the space of just a few months, Zoom Video Communications has become a household name-even a verb. But is that all the company is?

title: Biden's Change Beats Trump's Disruption
summary: Voters don't reject the president's personality but his hostility to institutions and standards of decency.. If you think President Trump is running behind on account of his bombastic style and divisive rhetoric, you're missing the forest for the trees. Voters knew who this guy was four years ago, and nearly half the country voted for him anyway. His campaign this year is collapsing because the American people are recoiling from the essence of his governing agenda. Mr. Trump's destructive record will define not only next month's election but also Republican politics for years to come.

title: Sen. Dumpty of Wonderland Votes Nay on Amy Coney Barrett
summary: Democrats threaten to pack the Supreme Court, then pretend not to know what the phrase means.. Somewhere in a hermetically sealed, surgically clean corner of the Democratic campaign war room, the message gnomes have been working overtime to come up with some clever verbal formulation to defend the indefensible.

title: Biden's Election Formula: It's About Two Big Themes, Man
summary: Democrat leads in polls because he has bored in on two messages: The country is ready to unify, and the coronavirus is a big deal. Donald Trump was elected president in 2016 in part because he understood a few big things about the country's mood, and stayed focused on them.

title: How Airbnb Pulled Back From the Brink
summary: Resume Subscription. In May, after fighting to keep Airbnb Inc. from the brink of collapse, Chief Executive Brian Chesky started noticing signs of life in part of his business.

title: Baseball Hall of Famer Joe Morgan Dies at 77
summary: A driving force of Cincinnati's Big Red Machine of the 1970s is considered by many to be the sport's greatest second baseman. CINCINNATI-Joe Morgan, the Hall of Fame second baseman who became the sparkplug of the Big Red Machine and the prototype for baseball's artificial turf era, has died. He was 77.

title: LeBron James Will Never Win Everyone Over. Who Cares. It's Silly.
summary: He's human. He makes mistakes. But to deny yourself the pleasure of watching the NBA's best player is to deny yourself joy.. LeBron James is an NBA champion and an NBA Finals MVP again, and it should briefly quell the usual, dreary harangues about his alleged shortcomings. I said "briefly." At 35, now in possession of four titles in three cities, James remains both an athlete and an argument, an easy vessel for anyone who wants to make a personal point about how much they don't like the NBA, modern sports, modern society, politics in sports, James's personal politics, what's happening in their hometown or city, or, I don't know, their oatmeal. Some of James's critics can blame James for almost anything; to co-opt a term deployed by defenders of a certain, other someone, James triggers a kind of LeBron Derangement Syndrome. For various reasons, there will always be some folks determined to loudly deny themselves the pleasure of watching one of the greatest athletes ever. This is anybody's right, of course. Some folks dislike beer and pizza. Humans are a mystery.

title: EU to Sanction Russia Over Poisoning and Belarus Leader Over Crackdown
summary: Bloc to penalize Russian officials allegedly involved in Navalny incident, and Lukashenko for repressing protesters. The European Union agreed Monday to impose targeted sanctions against Russian officials and entities allegedly involved in the poisoning of Russian opposition leader Alexei Navalny but officials insisted the move should not undercut Europe's continued high-level contacts with President Vladimir Putin.

title: Shedding Light on the Riddle of Lefties and Righties
summary: Many genes, not just one as believed earlier, seem to influence handedness, a new study suggests. A new study has handed important information to scientists mystified by lefties and righties.

title: Even Funeral Homes Are Getting Pinched by Amazon
summary: Covid-19 has produced what should be a bumper year for funeral homes, but a rise in cremations has pinched margins and created an opening for e-commerce. When death gives you lemons, make lemonade.

title: An Oceanfront Home in One of the Hamptons' Most Exclusive Enclaves Asks $52.5 Million
summary: The roughly 6,000-square-foot estate on Southampton's Meadow Lane belongs to the wife of a late Barneys New York chairman. A Hamptons estate owned by Phyllis Pressman, the wife of late Barneys New York department store Chairman Fred Pressman, is coming on the market for $52.5 million.

title: WSJ's Most Sustainably Managed Companies Finds Tatung and Kering Topping Innovation List
summary: The category's leaders come in two kinds: tech hardware and electronics, or clothing and footwear. Kering , the French luxury-goods conglomerate that owns Gucci and Balenciaga, says it can trace to their origins nearly 90% of the materials used by its many brands. The company measures and monitors the environmental impact of its supply chain and operations, and publishes its findings in an environmental profit-and-loss statement, which assigns a monetary value to the environmental footprint of its products like leather bags or cashmere sweaters.

title: Apple's New iPhone 12 With 5G Technology Carries High Expectations
summary: Some see the new smartphone spurring consumer upgrades and record sales, while others question the appeal of faster speeds. Apple is set on Tuesday to unveil a 5G-enabled iPhone that has fueled sky-high expectations for the world's most valuable company even as uncertainty remains about how useful the next-generation wireless technology is for consumers.

title: Bank of England Questions Lenders on Readiness for Negative Rates
summary: U.K. central bank sounds out lenders, as the Covid-19 crisis pushes policy makers into new territory. LONDON-The Bank of England asked British lenders to assess their readiness for subzero interest rates, a sign that officials are weighing the merits of a policy that bankers say would heap problems on a sector already weighed down by Covid-19 and Brexit.

title: An October Amazon Prime Day Opens a Remade Holiday Shopping Calendar
summary: Walmart, Target and others rush to spur sales now to contend with the shopping event, election uncertainty and a supply-chain crunch. Retailers want the holiday buying season to hit full speed in October as they brace for a sluggish and unpredictable end to the shopping year.

title: Opioid Crisis Pushes Drugmaker Mallinckrodt to File for Bankruptcy
summary: Drugmaker is the third pharmaceutical company to seek chapter 11 protection over lawsuits arising from the opioid crisis. Mallinckrodt PLC became the third drugmaker to seek chapter 11 protection over liabilities arising from the opioid crisis, and is proposing to implement a $1.6 billion settlement with state and local governments through the bankruptcy process.

title: LeBron James Is a Champion Again. He's Also a Bargain.
summary: He makes the same as other superstars because of the NBA's salary cap-but he's worth more than anyone. The sport's best player is the league's biggest market inefficiency.. NBA teams start every season with roughly the same pile of money and rules that prevent them from giving too much of it to one player. It doesn't matter if one team's superstar is superior to another's. They're probably going to be paid similar amounts regardless of who is actually better.

title: Twitter, Apple, PG&E, Twilio: What to Watch When the Stock Market Opens Today
summary: U.S. stock futures point to a muted advance when the market opens. Tech giants Apple and Twitter are among the biggest gainers.. Here's what we're watching as markets kick into gear Monday.

title: Mumbai Blackout Leaves Millions Without Power for Hours
summary: Failure in country's financial hub is seen as an embarrassment for India as it seeks to attract foreign investment and lure manufacturing away from China. NEW DELHI-India's financial capital, Mumbai, suffered one of its worst blackouts in decades as technical glitches caused its power-transmission network to shut down, leaving millions of people without power for hours on Monday.

title: Trump Books Fuel Record Sales of Political Titles
summary: Books on American politics are having a banner year ahead of the 2020 election, with President Obama's coming memoirs boding well for a fresh boost. Extraordinary demand for Trump-related books ahead of the Nov. 3 presidential election has put 2020 on pace to be a record sales year for political books.

title: How the WSJ Ranking of Sustainably Managed Companies Was Compiled
summary: The 100 most sustainably managed companies were determined using a blend of artificial intelligence and human validation. The Wall Street Journal's ranking of the world's most sustainably managed companies was based on a review of more than 5,500 publicly traded companies around the world that met disclosure standards for data showing what programs, policies and performance metrics they have in place for several key sustainability dimensions, including environment, human capital (internal employee and workplace issues), social capital (external social and product issues), and business model/innovation.

title: Santander Debt Surges as Investors Take a Risky Bet on Redemption
summary: A 16-year-old bond rallied 18% on Oct. 7, fueled by speculation that the bank may redeem the securities to avoid failing to make a coupon payment. Investors are betting Spanish lender Banco Santander SA won't be able to make interest payments on a risky form of bank debt. In a strange twist of events, instead of shunning the debt, investors are scooping it up.

title: Carla Bruni Received the Same Piece of Advice From Her Husband and Grandmother
summary: The former model's self-titled sixth album, released on October 9, was recorded in a little over a week when France's confinement lifted in June. In our series My Monday Morning, self-motivated people tell WSJ. how they start off the week.

title: Police Unions Fight to Keep Disciplinary Records Private
summary: Lawsuits try to block states' new laws and policies to increase transparency. Police unions in the tri-state region are fighting to block new measures that would give the public access to law-enforcement discipline records, which have long been confidential.

title: Ant Group Taps Millions of Its Own Users for Early-Bird IPO Funds
summary: The financial-technology giant raised nearly $9 billion from mutual funds sold on its platform to individual investors, who can't touch their money for 18 months. Ant Group Co. has deployed a novel approach to raise funds for its blockbuster initial public offering-by tapping millions of individuals that use Alipay, its popular mobile app.

title: British Airways CEO Departs as Parent IAG Seeks Revamp
summary: Aer Lingus boss to take the top job at British Airways amid senior management shuffle. LONDON- British Airways ' parent replaced the carrier's chief executive, moving to shake up the senior ranks at several of its most important airlines as the industry faces a crisis because of the pandemic.

title: The Senators to Watch During Amy Coney Barrett's Supreme Court Hearings
summary: A half-dozen Senate Judiciary Committee members will play especially notable roles during this week's hearings. WASHINGTON-The main focus during Amy Coney Barrett's Supreme Court confirmation hearings will be on the performance of the nominee herself, but the 22 lawmakers on the Senate Judiciary Committee will also get their moments in the spotlight.

title: The Los Angeles Lakers Win the NBA Title
summary: The league's longest season ended with LeBron James taking his fourth championship. The Los Angeles Lakers made a bet at the very beginning of the longest, rockiest season in NBA history that any team with LeBron James and Anthony Davis could win a championship.

title: Central Banks Haven't Made a Convincing Case for Digital Currencies
summary: It remains unclear what benefits e-money would bring to offset risks to bank funding and financial stability. Central bankers should avoid getting too drawn into the bitcoin buzz.

summary: The successful IPO of K-pop producer Big Hit Entertainment gives the company big resources, but it needs to diversify from its sole money-spinner. Korean pop music, or K-pop, has taken the world by storm. It is shaking up the financial markets, too.

title: Prescott Is Latest NFL Star to Be Lost to Injury
summary: In a season already disrupted by health and safety concerns due to the pandemic, the Cowboys quarterback joins high-profile stars including Saquon Barkley and Nick Bosa on the sidelines. The 2020 NFL season has already been repeatedly disrupted by the health and safety problem menacing the entire country: the coronavirus pandemic. When Dallas Cowboys quarterback Dak Prescott went down Sunday with a gruesome ankle injury, he put an uncomfortable face on the other health and safety problem upending America's most popular sport: injuries to the game's best and most popular players.

title: How Investors Are Trading November's Election
summary: Resume Subscription. With market volatility rising ahead of November's U.S. presidential and Congressional elections, investors are parsing what polls and policy proposals mean for everything from energy stocks to shares of private-prison operators.

title: As Coronavirus Infections Rise in Europe, So Do Travel Restrictions
summary: European Union aims to bring order to a growing patchwork of travel rules. European countries are tightening cross-border travel restrictions as they try to rein in a surge in coronavirus infections and prepare for a possible further increase with the arrival of cold weather.

title: Venture Capital Struggles to Boost Funding for Startups With Women Founders
summary: Some progress has been made at young companies, but a surge of giant late-stage funding deals largely left female entrepreneurs on the sidelines. Sara Jensen believes venture capitalists want to back female entrepreneurs. That's why, when it came time for the startup she launched with her husband to raise seed-stage funding, she took charge of reaching out to investors.

summary: No stock has been more heavily attacked by activist short sellers than GSX Techedu, but the Chinese tutoring company has so far come out on top. No stock has been more heavily attacked by activist short sellers this year than GSX Techedu Inc., a New York-listed Chinese tutoring company.

summary: 'Odd lot' buying in mortgage portfolios attracts scrutiny. When fund made its debut in late May 2015, it began to beat its peers almost immediately, an unusual development for the slow-moving world of bond investing.

summary: Central bank makes it easier to bet the currency will fall in value. China made it easier for traders to bet the yuan will fall in value, a move analysts said showed that the country's central bank wants to slow any further rally in the currency.

summary: Resume Subscription. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: What to Expect From Bank Earnings: A Bad Quarter, but Not as Bad as Before
summary: Seven months into the coronavirus pandemic, banks are getting used to a sour economy. The U.S. economy is settling in for a lengthy recovery. Earnings from the largest banks are expected to make that clear.
